text: Women's casual wear department. J.C. Penny. Legend "1961" An African-American man carrying two J.C. Penny shopping department store managers and security guards on walkies the entrance to the woman's dressing rooms.

A bed has been formed by a chair and three benches. A STRIKING AFRICAN-AMERICAN WOMAN in her twenties lays ac clothes are covered in sweat. Her skirt is stained. She holds something wrapped in a soft sweatshirt on her c but WE HEAR THE BABY CRYING. She's just given birth. There are three frazzled saleswomen in the dressing room with quiet smiles. A fourth SALESWOMAN arrives ushering in the man with the
This is Mr. Mathison. He's a doctor. DR. MATHISON looks over the scene and then directly at th
You okay? The woman nods, "Yes." Sweat trickles down her face. THE ECHO IN THE SMALL ROOM.
An ambulance is on the way. Dr. Mathison puts down his shopping bags and moves to her gestures for the bundle of sweatshirts in her arms.
Is there a name yet? Beat. The woman smiles for the first time.
Elijah. She hands him the wrapped child. We can't see the baby, b SEEM TO GET LOUDER.

Is he supposed to be crying like that? The doctor lowers the baby to his lap and unwraps him. The woman can't see her baby anymore. She watches Dr. Mat and examines her child. Beat. Dr. Mathison doesn't look u

Can I have him back? THE BABY'S CRYING IS RELENTLESS. UNNERVING. Beat. The doctor finally glances up. He looks shaken. He makes woman for only a second. It's enough. A chill goes throug He looks to the three saleswomen who were in the room.
What happened during the delivery? His hard stare unsettles the women. The OLDER SALESWOMAN
Nothing. It was very quick. The baby just wanted to come right out. There was no problems.
Did you drop him? Everyone becomes very still. The mother looks like she st BABY'S SCREAMING ENGULFS THE ROOM.
Did you drop this baby? Beat.
Jesus Christ, no. The BABY SCREAMS. The doctor whispers something to himself, we can't hear. saleswoman who brought him in.
Please inform the ambulance we have a situation... Dr. Mathison turns back to the mother. Beat.
I've never seen this... It appears your infant sustained some fractures while in your uterus. (beat)
His arms and legs are broken.

text: A fountain of humanity bubbles up from the escalators to Businessmen take their last desperate drags of their ciga traveling with children herd their luggage and offspring they move... College students with backpacks look around track numbers. ANNOUNCER(o.s.)

Last call track three, Amtrak Clocker making it's final stop at Philadelphia's thirtieth street station. First two passenger cars only. First two cars only. A face inside the train watches the stream of passengers escalators. DAVID DUNNE, a man in his early forties, rest glass and quietly observes the movement outside. The train starts to pull out.

David sits with his coat on his lap. He's wearing a tie. comfortable in it. He feels a stare. He looks up to find a girl, six or seve him from over the seat in front of him. She just gazes at He gives her a small forced smile. She doesn't react. Dav the window. His eyes begin to shut with the lulling movement of the t WOMAN(o.s.)

You alone? David looks in the direction of THE VOICE. A WOMAN with d eyes stands in the aisle with two bags over her shoulder. white t-shirt and jeans. She's beautiful. David nods "yes." The woman starts putting her bags on the shelf above the get them up. Her toned stomach is exposed. She has a silv her navel. David has a gold ring on his hand. He fiddles with it. Be his wedding band. It goes into his coat pocket. The woman takes the seat next to him. Beat. A LOUD VIOLENT BURST OF SOUND. The passenger car sh train barrels by two feet from David's window. It passes car returns to a QUIET HUM. David pulls a magazine out from the seat pocket in front He holds the woman's fashion magazine out.
Someone left these. You want one? The woman looks over the one being offered and then point Illustrated peeking out of the seat pocket. David pulls the magazine out and gives it to her.
You like sports?
It's my field. I represent athletes. I'm an agent.
What a coincidence? I'm a male synchronized swimmer and I'm looking for representation. WOMAN(smiling)
Is that right?
But I'm afraid of water, so that's been holding my career back a little bit. The woman laughs.
You represent someone in Philadelphia?
I'm meeting a player from Temple University. He's a cornerback. You like football? Beat.
Not really.

This kid is six foot two, two hundred and forty pounds. He runs the fifty in under six seconds. He's going to be a God. Beat. David studies the excitement in her eyes. ANOTHER LOUD VIOLENT BURST OF SOUND. David waits till the The woman goes back to her magazine. Beat.
I'm David Dunne. The woman looks up.
Kelly. She goes back to the magazine. Beat.
How long are you staying in Philly? KELLY looks up from her Sports Illustrated. Her striking Beat. She holds up her hand. Taps the diamond ring on her finge KELLY(soft)
I'm married. DAVID(fake excitement)
Great. Beat.
Sorry. DAVID(fake confusion)
What are you talking about? An awkward silence.
I think you got the wrong idea. The woman stares at David. She looks down. Beat. Closes t

I'm going to find another seat. Kelly gets up. She balances herself against a headrest as starts to the back of the car. David sits alone. He looks like he's drowning, but there' He feels a stare. He glances up. The little girl spies on seats. David leans towards the window to avoid eye contact. His coat and slides out his wedding band. He puts it back on. His temple touches the glass. The vibration of the train closed... Beat. David's head bounces lightly against the window. The shaking of the glass never allows David's eyes to com He sits up when he realizes the shaking is getting strong He looks out the window. The scenery blurs as it flies by David turns. Some of the other passengers start to react train is picking up speed. The normal bumps of the tracks become amplified. The WORRIED VOICES OF THE TRAVELERS START FILL THE CABIN. The train goes faster.

TAKE A CURVE.

TRACK...

text: A boy, age ten, sits on his head on the family couch and upside down. His floppy brown hair spreads out in a circl face. He changes channels with a remote control. He moves past the upside down cartoons and the upside dow on an upside down picture of a crashed train. Beat. His knees come forward as he flips over. He tumbles slowl the carpet. JEREMY DUNNE gazes at the television screen.. A TRAIN WRECK SMOULDERING BELOW IS SEEN. Two trains are t Jeremy gets up and moves to a small table with a phone. N notepad. On it is written... "Dad - Amtrak 177 - 3:40pm." Jeremy looks at the television. At the bottom of the scre that move from right to left are words and numbers..."The derailed... Amtrak Emergency number is 1-800-777-4322... derailed...Amtrak" Jeremy doesn't take his eyes off the screen. He makes a s that no one hears.

An elderly woman can't hold back any longer and SCREAMS. helpless scream. MEGAN DUNNE continues applying pressure to her arm which far as it will go. She counts to three and eases off. She lays her arm back WE ARE IN A PHYSICAL THERAPY CENTER. About a dozen people weight machines. The elderly woman is seated on an exercise table and brea
You okay, Virginia? Beat. VIRGINIA shakes her head, "No."

I'll put something on the t.v. Maybe we'll find some almost naked guys to inspire you. Megan reaches up to the t.v. monitor mounted on the wall. starts flipping channels. She stops on ESPN where a swimm Men in bikini swimsuits line the edges of the pool. Virginia starts watching with great interest. Megan's eyes move to the tiny print moving across the bot face goes still as she reads the train number... 177.

head_text.subj: DAVID DUNNE'S EYES SLOWLY OPEN. THE DULL WHITE OF THE OVE
BLINDS HIM AT FIRST.

text: He blinks his vision back. He realizes he's in a bed. WE HEAR AGITATED VOICES, MOVEMENT. David looks around. He's in an emergency room. There are and beds next to him. They're all empty.

head_text.subj: DAVID FOLLOWS THE URGENT SOUNDS OF ACTIVITY TO A PREP ARE
HIM.

text: He can only see glimpses of activity through the drawn cu emergency room personnel are treating a man whose body is a gurney. One of the group is a man who glances through the opening notices David sitting up from across the room. THE MAN IN SCRUBS leaves the group and walks over.
How are you feeling?
Okay. He FLASHES A LIGHT in David's eyes.
You are in the emergency room of the University of Pennsylvania Hospital. You were in a serious accident. (beat)
How's your vision?
Fine. David stares across as the scene with the other patients disturbing.
Where were you sitting on the train?
Against a window.
In the passenger car?
Yes. Where are the rest of the passengers?
Was your family traveling with you?
No.
Did you get up from your seat?
No. David watches the other patient.
You're certain you were in the passenger car? David turns to the man.
Yes... Why are you looking at me like that? Beat.

Your train derailed... Some kind of malfunction... It took a curve way to fast. A second train collided with yours after it derailed. The debris is spread over one mile. It's unbelievable they said. (beat)
They only found two people alive so far... You and him. David looks to the other passenger now laying unnaturally whirlwind of activity around him.
The man's skull was cracked open and most of his left side was crushed. Beat.
And to answer your question, there are two reasons why I'm looking at you like this. David turns and stares at the man.
One, because it seems, in a few minutes, you will officially be the only survivor of this train wreck. (beat)
And two, because you don't have a scratch on you. You didn't break one bone.
David moves through the depressing milky corridors of the set of double doors. A room crammed with cameras and photographers explodes wi A CHILD'S VOICE BREAKS THEIR NOISE.

I told you! Jeremy Dunne pushes forward through the mob of people and and runs to David. He wraps his arms around David's waist there, aware that the cameras are catching it all. He's o Hospital staff and a couple police officers push the medi Jeremy tugs David to lean down. He does.
They thought everybody on the train died. David looks at his son's face. Wipes the tears on his che
I told them they were wrong. A woman moves to them. David stands up and faces Megan Du
Mom even cried. David looks at Megan's eyes.
A lot. Megan looks away.
Not a lot. They stand there for a moment. David looks shaken. Jeremy
Let's go home. Megan nods. They move to the exit. The pack of cameras an life as they leave the building. They jockey for position of David Dunne.
David eats a bowl of pasta alone in a modest kitchen. He Opens and closes it slowly. Beat. He rises and puts the bowl away in the sink.
David stops just before rising the stairs. He glances int bottom of the stairs. The doorway is half open. He makes wife. Beat.
I don't think I got the job in New York.
What does that mean?
I'm still going to New York. Just not this second.
I don't want to drag this out too long for Jeremy.
I know. Beat.
How about in the meantime, you don't sleep in the guestroom anymore? (beat)
You sleep in our room. I'll sleep down here. Beat.
It stopped being our room a long time ago. (beat)
You should go up and get some rest. Beat. Megan slowly closes the door to the guest bedroom.
David looks at his son asleep in his bed.
Jeremy, why don't you go sleep with your mom? JEREMY(eyes closed)
I want to sleep here tonight.
I think it's be better if I was alone. JEREMY(eyes closed)
I won't make any noise.
How about your room then? If you get scared like before, you can come back in here? Beat. Jeremy doesn't answer because he's asleep. David ru up. He turns on the t.v., low volume, as he moves into th
Hot water rushes over David's face as he stands in the sh drawn to the t.v. which is seen through the slightly open He turns off the water to HEAR. NEWS ANCHOR(t.v.)

...Derailed approximately seven and half miles outside Philadelphia. It came to rest on its side on the northbound tracks. It is train officials belief that some if not most of the passengers were still alive at this time. NEWS ANCHOR(t.v.)

The momentary peace lasted only a few seconds. A Boston bound freight train on the northbound tracks was seconds away from passing train 177 when it derailed. The impact happened at about three-fifteen p.m. The first of the two occupied passenger cars was severed in half and sent careening in two directions. The second of the passenger cars was crushed and dragged for four hundred feet. Six crew members were on the freight. One hundred and eighteen passengers and seven crew members were on the passenger train... There is one reported survivor. (beat)

Rescue teams will be working for the next forty-eight hours removing bodies and debris. David steps out of the shower. He sees a glimpse of Jerem shuts the door. Locks it. He gets back into the shower and turns the water back on. He closes his eyes. His face tightens up. He slowly hunch on the tiled floor of the shower. Water pours over him. I won't get hurt momma! I'm safe!

The t Elijah's eyes fill with joy as the wind plays against his Suddenly the ride changes directions. The cup-like seats grabs the metal bars to hold on. text: MOTHER(o.s.)
His bones... He's not well...
MOTHER(o.s.)

Elijah baby... Then her face appears as she finds the cup-like seat Elij scream. Elijah lays on the bottom of the compartment. One arm is other is curved horrifically like an "s". His mouth is op bulging. The last thing we HERE ARE THE SHORT DESPERATE B old child about to black out from the pain.

WE EMERGE FROM BLACK to find news vans and reporters lini from a church. They have been cordoned off by a handful o recorded as they emerge from their cars and enter the chu David is among the arriving crowd. MAN(o.s.)

David Dunne! At hearing his name, David turns back as he walks. He can called his name because all of them seem to react. A stor the group jockeys for the best angle of his troubled face David passes a magnetic board as he enters the church. It the families and friends of train 177."
A PRIEST stands before a podium.
Sarah Elaston, social worker at Broad and Locust Community Center. We pray for your soul. (beat)
Kevin Elliott, business man, father of six. We pray for your soul. (beat)

Glen Stevens, researcher in the area of Leukemia at Drexel University. We pray for your soul. David sits amongst the mourners in the standing room only to a woman two rows ahead of him. She's turned around, lo are red  from crying. David looks away. His eyes stop on an old man far to his away. Father, mother and daughter stare silently. David surveys the entire church... Desperate inconsolable existence from every direction. David has to look down.
...Jennifer Pennyman, third grade teacher at Jefferson Elementary. (beat)
We pray for your soul.
David and the priest who conducted the mass are alone in room. The priest looks in his fifties, eyes tired, blood
I used to play football in college. In my first year as quarterback, we went on this winning streak. It just went on and on. It didn't matter who we played... I'd always win. (beat)

You get superstitious when something like that happens. You give things meaning. Like you wear the same color socks each game or you listen to the same B.B. King song before you leave the apartment. I wouldn't even untie the shoelaces on my cleats. I'd just slip them on and off so nothing would change... I gave things meaning that had no meaning. (beat)
I'm here to make sure I'm not making shoelaces into something they're not again. (beat)
I was the only person to survive that accident. The only one... It feels like it means something. Beat.
Are you a religious man, David? David nods, "No." The priest removes the sacred stoll from his around his n folding it carefully.
Good. Because I'm going to talk to you as a man. Not as a man of the cloth.
Okay. Beat. The priest turns to David.
It was luck. Beat.
What do you mean?
Luck... Random... Without meaning. David just sits awkwardly.
Three years ago, my cousin died on a plane that crashed on take off at Philadelphia International airport. Do you remember that crash? David nods, "Yes."

I prayed and prayed and finally found some meaning in the event. It gave me peace... And then not quite a year later, an entire family from my parish burned to death in a hotel fire downtown... (beat)
Again I prayed. Again I found  meaning. (beat)
Just two days ago, my nephew rode with you on that train back from New York. He was traveling alone for the first time.
I'm sorry if I can't react to your survival with the appropriate 'It was the hand of God. It was a miracle.' kind of answer... I'm fresh out of those right now. David is shaken. Beat. DAVID(soft)
The metal of the watch I was wearing was crushed like a sledge hammer hit it. Beat. The priest's eyes fill with emotion.
My twelve year old nephew's neck was broken in four places... What's your point? You were chosen? (beat)
I don't think so. The priest turns and continues putting away artifacts fro fills the back room.

No cameras greet his exit. No people anywhere. David walks across the now empty parking lot. His car is He walks to the driver's side. Pulls out his keys. That's His eyes catch sight of the GRAY ENVELOPE tucked under th his car. David moves forward and gently pulls it out. His name is turns it over. Two embossed words on the back. "Limited Edition"
He opens the envelope. One line, handwritten, gazes at hi card. The line reads...
How many days of your life have you been sick?
Nothing else is written. David Dunne looks around the empty parking lot quietly.

A poorly lit changing room. A row of metallic lockers sit bench splits the room. A brown folding table with Dunkin on it is crammed in the corner. A puke colored concrete f David and three other large men are changing out of their all put on the same yellow short sleeve shirts. The same all their backs... "Stadium Security" This ritual goes on without a word.

David walks along the massive curved wall around the oute he passes the different walkways we get glimpses of the e sixty-thousand seat football stadium on the inside. David stops at a door marked "PERSONNEL".
David knocks on the door as he steps into the cramped rec personnel office. The SECRETARY, an ancient woman with thick flabby arms ne never looks up as she talks.
Yes?
Is Noel in?
No sir he is not. (beat)
I read about you in the paper.
Oh.
I was in an accident once too. A horse almost trampled me to death.
Wow.
I had to put him down. Beat.
That's a sad story. (beat)
Do you think you could ask Noel something for me? The ancient secretary's right hand immediately picks up a over a blank pad. Her left hand keeps typing. She never l
Proceed.
Ask if he can check how many sick days I've taken since I've worked here? Beat.
Is that the entire message?
Yes.

Rain falls in sheets in the stadium. David stands at the entrance to a tunnel that empties out stands in an imposing dark green rain poncho and hood. Th the ground. The word 'security' on the back has almost fa see David's face under the hood. There is a football game in progress on the enormous fiel unusually small. There is no one in the stands. About fou the sidelines of the field watching the players. A soggy behind them declares, "The Pennslvania Elementary School David's eyes scan the tiny figures on the field. His eyes activity on the sidelines. Beat. David steps out into the rain.

A handful of red faced fathers are yelling at each other. rain soaked faces. The scene feels on the verge of physic David and another security guard jog over. David steps in circle. The men stop yelling in the presence of stadium s stands in the rain glaring at each other. Beat.

You know what I think about to calm down? I think about those big fat, hundred and twenty pound turtles that live in the islands. Those suckers never get angry, never get in fights and live longer than all of us and all they do all is sit on the beach and hump other turtles. (beat)
Why don't we take a second and think about the turtles? Nobody moves. Rain washes over the agitated faces. A fath

Yeah Jerry why don't you think about the fat ass turtles... Like your fat ass son on the field jeopardizing the rest of our chances at a fucking championship. David tenses. Everyone looks to JERRY. A bald man who sta Jerry nods to himself. Looks like he's going to say somet forward and smashes a HEADBUTT to the man who spoke to hi David tackles Jerry hard and fast. He drives him into the Blood starts rushing out of the nose of the dazed father The other fathers start yelling and pushing each other. T guard calls on his walkie for assistance. David keeps Jerry immobilized in a powerful arm and head man's enraged face hard into the wet surface of the field David's eyes are not on Jerry. They gaze out onto the fie elementary school boys have stopped playing and are stand rain washing over their faces. They watch in horror as th other on the sidelines.
David is the last one left. He's showered and back in his in the dimly lit room on the bench, lost in his thoughts He turns to find a somewhat pregnant looking man with a t NOEL.
Hey Noel. Beat. He just stares.
Forty dollars. David turns on the bench.
What?
You're getting a forty dollar raise per week... that's it. Silence.
I checked. You were right. You've never taken a sick day. (beat)
Five years, no sick days. I get it. You want a raise. You made your point. The room is still. Beat.
All right fifty dollars and that's the god damn limit. (beat)
Are we done here? Beat. David nods, "Yes."

head_text.subj: LIGHTS OUT.

text: David is wide awake in his bed. He glances over. Jeremy i him.
David knocks again quietly. The guest bedroom door opens. Megan looks up at David. She's just woken up. MEGAN(low voice)
Is Jeremy okay? DAVID(low voice)
He's asleep. MEGAN(low voice)
Oh. Beat. They both stand awkwardly for a moment. DAVID(low voice)
I wanted to ask you a question. It'll sound strange, but just think about it for a second. Megan nods, "Yes." DAVID(low voice)
When's the last time I was sick? You remember? Megan tries to mask her reaction to the oddness of the qu MEGAN(low voice)
I don't know. It's been a while. DAVID(low voice)
I haven't been sick this year. I know that. MEGAN(low voice)
Okay. DAVID(low voice)
Do you remember me getting sick? MEGAN(low voice)
Not a specific day. What's this about? DAVID (low voice)
Megan, do you  ever remember me getting sick? Beat. DAVID(low voice)
In the three years we've been in this house?... In the old apartment?... Before Jeremy was born?... Before we were married? Beat. MEGAN(low voice)
...I can't remember. DAVID(low voice)
That's strange isn't it? Not remembering one fever... Or a cold... Or a sore throat. What do you think that means? MEGAN(low voice)
It means we're probably to tired to remember. David becomes quiet as he thinks. Beat. MEGAN(low voice)
Is that what you wanted to ask me? DAVID(low voice)
Yes. MEGAN(low voice)
Is there anything else you wanted to ask me while I'm up?... MEGAN(low voice)
...When was the last time you wore pink? When was the last time you drank soup standing up? Final call for strange questions at two in the morning. DAVID(low voice)
No that's it. David seems lost in his thoughts. MEGAN(low voice)
Maybe you should go up. Jeremy might see you're gone and get frightened. (beat)
The train thing, really shook him up. He's scared something's going to happen to you. He doesn't want to let you out of his sight. David stares at Megan. Beat. DAVID(low voice)
Yeah. I know. There's silence for a bit. DAVID(low voice)
When was the last time I wore pink? MEGAN(low voice)
The Mitchell barbecue three years ago. DAVID(realizing)
Oh shit... MEGAN(low voice)
Matching shirt and shorts. It was brutal. David half-smiles as Megan turns and starts back into the DAVID(low voice)
Goodnight Megan. Megan looks back at her husband. Just for a moment. Then MEGAN(low voice)
Goodnight David. Megan closes the door slowly shut.
WE EMERGE in a cramped sparse bedroom.

head_text.subj: LEGEND "1974"

text: A thirteen year old Elijah sits in a chair with his arm i small black and white television in the corner of the roo WE HEAR FOOTSTEPS. Elijah's mother walks into the room. S moment, and then moves to the television. Turns it off. The room GOES SILENT.
No more sitting in this room. I've let it go on long enough.
I'm not going out anymore. I'm not getting hurt again. This was the last time. I told you.

You can't do anything about that. You might fall between that chair and this television. If that's what God has planned for you, that's what's going to happen. You can't hide from it in your room. Elijah just sits staring at the dark television screen.
They call me Mr. Glass at school. Cause I break like glass. Elijah's face is tense. Unyielding. Beat. Elijah's mother says the next words in almost a whisper.
...You make this decision now to be afraid... (beat)
And you'll never turn back your whole life. You'll always be afraid. Elijah's eyes move from the television to his mother. He face. Neither says anything for a while. Beat.
...I got a present for you.
Why?
Forget why. Do you want it or not? Elijah thinks it over. He nods, "Yes."
Well, go get it then.
Where is it?
On a bench, across the street. Elijah looks at his mother with disbelief.

You calling me a liar? She points to the window. Beat. Elijah gets up and moves the room. The view from his room looks out over a narrow street. On street is a public playground. A handful of children are There are three benches to one side of the swings. On one PACKAGE wrapped in brown paper with a bow on it. Elijah looks to his mom who has joined him at the window.
Someone's gonna take it. Beat.
Then you better get out there soon.

Elijah walks across the playground. He's very wary of the about him. He walks towards the bench with the present on it. Takes on his lap. It's flat. The edges of the bend down over hi He undoes the white bow. He peels off the clear tape hold together. He unfolds the paper. Beat. Elijah stares down at the single comic book in his lap. He feels the shadow of his mother. She takes a seat next
I bought a whole bunch. They'll be one of these waiting for you, every time you want to come out here. Beat.
They said this one has a surprise ending. Elijah looks to his mother. His intelligent piercing eyes moment. He looks back down at his lap. He opens the first page...

The same intelligent piercing eyes, twenty-five years old into a handsome, regal looking man. He leans on a walking He's looking at an impressively framed charcoal sketch on depicted on the top of a building locked in fierce battle extremely muscular with a mask. The other is half human,
This is from Fritz Champion's own library. This is before the first issue of the comic book hit the stands in 1968. Elijah glances at the BUSINESS MAN standing next to him a sketch.

It's a classic depiction of good versus evil. Notice the square jaw of Slayer - common in most comic book heroes. And the slightly disproportionate size of Jaguaro's body to his head. This again is common, but only in villains... The thing to notice about this piece... The thing that makes it very, very special... is its realistic depiction of its figures. When the characters eventually made it into the magazine they were exaggerated... as always happens. (beat)
This is vintage. The business man rubs his face. Gazes at the sketch. Beat
Wrap it up.
You've made a considerably wise decision. Elijah starts to the back of the store which we now see i gallery where all the framed pictures are images and sket
My kid's gonna go berserk. Elijah jams his walking stick into the extra thick carpet
Once again please?
My son Jeb. It's a gift for him.
How old is Jeb?
Four.
No. Elijah starts back to the businessman shaking his head st
No, no, no, no no... You need to go now.
What did I say?

Do you see any Telletubbies around here?... Do you see a slender plastic tag clipped to my shirt with my name printed on it?... Do you see a little Asian child with a blank expression sitting outside in a mechanical helicopter that shakes when you put a quarter in it?... No?... Well that's what you see at a toy store? Any you must think this is a toy store, cause you're in here shopping for an infant named Jeb. One of us has made a gross error and wasted the other person's valuable time... Elijah's eyes pierce through the shaken man.
This is an art gallery my friend. This is piece of art... Elijah points at the sketch.

This is one of seventeen original drawings by Fritz Champion remaining in the world. It's value will triple every year... This piece is to be treasured. To be cherished... To be coveted by every single one of your banker friends that think they're better than you. The business man stares at the sketch with large eyes. Be
What if I kept it? Beat.
I'm listening.
I'll keep it in my office room.
What about Jeb?
I have a lock on the door. Elijah just stares.
Will it be near a window?
No direct sunlight will fall on it. Elijah eyes the man for many seconds. Beat.
Come back in three days. I'll think about it. Elijah starts to the back. He passes the front door as tw Elijah talks over his shoulder to them.
We're by appointment only.
I received a card from your store.
Congratulations, you have a mailbox... The sale isn't for two weeks.

This one was under the windshield of my car. Elijah turns and faces the customers for the first time. Jeremy. Elijah just stands staring for the longest time. Beat. He When Elijah speaks, his voice has a whispery quality to i
You've never been sick?
I don't know for sure. (beat)
...I don't think so. David and Elijah quietly look at each other. Beat.
Well if this ain't a riddle worthy of the Riddler?

Three chairs have been placed on the walkway in front of store. The words, "Limited Edition" are etched in the win David, Jeremy and Elijah are seated watching the people s is on his lap. Jeremy sips a drink in a paper cup.
So let's get some of the usual questions out of the way. Why am I using a cane? Raise your hand if you were thinking that. Jeremy raises his hand.
I fractured my leg. It's the fifth time I've done that particular bone. It didn't really heal well this time.
Raise your hand is you're wondering who the hell breaks the same bone five times? Jeremy and David raise their hands.

I have something called Osteogenesis Imperfecta. It's a genetic disorder. I don't make this particular type of protein very well and it makes my bones very low in density, very easy to break. I've had fifty-four breaks in my life. I have the tamest version of the disorder... Type one. (beat)
There are type two, type three, and type four. Type four's don't make it very long... (beat)
That ends our lecture on the medical anomaly known as Elijah Price. Elijah stares at his two rapt listeners.
How certain are you that you haven't been sick in your life?
Seventy-five percent.
Seventy-five percent? That's not nearly good enough for me. I'm extremely skeptical.
Skeptical about what?
Your answer to my question. It's one thing to have never been injured in your life, but to state that you've never taken ill, well that's a whole new level.
Dad's been injured. Beat.
What's he talking about?
In college. A car accident.
Was it serious? David nods.
He couldn't play football anymore. Beat. Elijah looks shaken.
I assumed because of the train.
You assumed wrong. Elijah closes his eyes. When his eyes open, the life forc diminished. Beat.
It's over. (beat)
You can go now. Elijah uses his cane to get up and walk back through the
David and Jeremy enter the store. Elijah leans on a walki the framed sketches. He gazes at it quietly.
I think you skipped a couple steps. Elijah turns.
You forgot the "Now I'm going to tell you what the hell is going on" step. See usually that comes before the, "It's over" Step. And it always, always comes before the "You can go" Step. (beat)
What is over?
The life of an idea that has lived too long in my head. David stares at Elijah impatiently.

There are probably only four or five individuals in the world who can claim more knowledge of comics than myself. I've spent a third of my life in a hospital bed with nothing else to do but read. I have studied the form intimately. I have seen the patterns in them... The references to social and cultural events and the atmosphere that surrounded them. I've come to believe that comics are our last link to the ancient way of passing on history.
The Egyptians drew pictures on walls about battles, and events. Countries all around the world still pass on knowledge through pictorial forms. (beat)

I believe that comics, just at their core now... have a truth. They are depicting what someone, somewhere felt or experienced. Then of course that core got chewed up in the commercial machine and gets jazzed up, made titillating - cartooned for the sale rack. Elijah gazes at David.

This city has had its share of disasters. Well publicized ones. It was around the time of that plane crash, when it first entered my head. And there it stayed, as I waited and watched the news over the years... (beat)
And then one day I see a news report on a train accident and its sole survivor who was miraculously unharmed. (soft)
And just like that, an idea blossoms into the flower of possible reality.
What was your idea Elijah? Beat. ELIJAH(soft)
If there is someone like me in the world, and I'm at one end of the spectrum... Couldn't there be someone the opposite of me, at the other end? (beat)
A person who can't be hurt like the rest of us. A kind of person they were talking about in those stories. Elijah points at the framed comic sketches. ELIJAH(soft)
A person they believed was put here to protect the rest of us. Guard us.
You thought my dad was a real-
Jeremy don't take another sip of that drink. Jeremy looks down at the paper cup in his hands.
Throw it in the trashcan near the door and wait for me outside. Do it now please. David waits for Jeremy to exit the store. Beat.
At the church... You were following me weren't you?
Technically no. I gambled that you would attend the church service. I just waited for you. David glares at Elijah.
What's this about? This is obviously some scam. Is this where you tell me one of those pictures is like an investment?
You've misunderstood.

I see guys like you all the time in my work. You find someone you think is emotionally vulnerable and you tell them a fantastic story, utterly convincing... and somewhere in there, you slip it in... 'I just need your credit card number','I just need a small down payment.' David shakes his head. He smiles out of frustration. Beat
Did you know that this morning was the first morning I can remember, that I didn't open my eyes and feel that sadness... Do you know what I'm talking about? That little bit of sadness? (beat)
I thought the person that wrote that note had an answer for me. For why I survived that train. For why my life feels so out of balance... (beat)
But I guess that's what you were counting on. Elijah stares carefully at David. Beat. David glances ove Jeremy watched through the window concerned.
I'm going to leave now. (beat)
Good luck with your sale. Elijah watches David walk towards the front door.
What type of job do you have David? David opens the door. He looks back at Elijah.
You mentioned you've met 'guys like me' in your work. (beat)
What type of job would that be? Beat.

I work at the stadium as a security guard. Beat. David closes the door behind him. Elijah watches th Jeremy takes David's hand as they cross the street. Elijah gazes out the window in a bit of a daze.

head_text.subj: ALL LIGHTS ARE OUT EXCEPT THE SMALL BEDSIDE LAMP ON DAVID

text: David sits up in bed staring at a torn section of newspap Jeremy is asleep horizontally with his legs over David's David doesn't blink as he gazes at the headline silently.

head_text.subj: "TRAIN CRASH DEATH TOLL CONFIRMED AT 131 DEAD. 1 SURVIVOR

text: Beat. David slides out from under his son's legs. Jeremy up. David moves to the darkness of the corner of the room. He A NAKED HANGING BULB GOES ON as David yanks a chain. Davi narrow closet and closes the door slightly so the LIGHT F FALL ON JEREMY. There's just enough room to stand and look around. David small travel bag out of the way. David stretches as he fe His hand comes down with something wrapped in a t-shirt. handgun. He stares at it for a beat before wrapping it back up and highest shelf. He stretches even more. Reaches farther back. WE HEAR SOM SHELF AS HE PULLS IT FORWARD. He pulls down a folder jammed with clippings. He opens th young David in football uniform holding his helmet in the word "Champion" is written over his head. David flips thr - all are images and stories of David and football. He turns the pile over. Goes to the last clipping. This p over three times, unlike the others. He opens it. It's a newspaper headline. It reads...

head_text.subj: "CAR ACCIDENT LEAVES TWO INJURED"

text: David puts the new headline next to the old one... They l font is similar. David stares at the old headline. Stares hard at the phot heavily damaged car laying upside down in the middle of t seems to flicker. David is utterly still. SOMEONE KNOCKS AT THE BEDROOM DOOR. David gets startled. He puts back the clippings. Stuffing the new one inside w back to the top shelf and leaves the closet. ANOTHER SOFT SET OF KNOCKS as David moves across the bedr Megan stands in the darkened hall. Beat. DAVID(whisper)
Hi. Megan nods. Beat. MEGAN(whisper)
I've come to a decision. DAVID(whisper)
Oh. Beat. MEGAN(whisper)
Let me just ask you something okay? And you can be totally honest. I'm prepared for any answer. It won't affect me... David nods, "yes." MEGAN(whisper)
Have you  been with anyone? Since we started having problems? The answer won't affect me. Beat. David stares at his wife. MEGAN(whisper)

It won't affect me either way. Beat. David doesn't say anything. He just nods, "No." Megan's face starts to tremble. She starts crying. Tears affected face. She tries to wipe them away, but there's t MEGAN(soft)
...My decision is... I'd like to start again. Pretend we're at the beginning. (beat)
It's a big deal you walked away from that train. It's a second chance. (beat)
If you want to ask me out sometime, that would be okay. Megan nods and walks down the stairs as she wipes her fac disappear into the shadows.

Sunday afternoon. The cavernous stadium opens up into a p The Philadelphia Eagles pro football players are in unifo on the field. The opposing team warms up on the other end The sixty thousand seats are already half filled as fans of the stadium.

A line of ticket holders snakes towards two turnstiles wh ripping tickets. David Dunne stands to one side with two other security gu The fans moving through the turnstiles are clad in all ty paraphernalia. A group of girls carries a homemade banner tilts his head sideways. "We sleep with quarterbacks," is letters. David stares at a woman carrying a newborn infant in her wearing an eagles uniform. The WALKIE TALKIE on David's hip bursts to life. He pulls listens.
Dunne, it's Jenkins, we got a guy at gate 17C with a bogus ticket. Says he knows you. He won't tell me his name. DAVID(into walkie)
What's he look like?
He's got the most beautiful eyes... The hell kind of question is that? He's a guy. DAVID(into walkie)
Send him packing. I'm not walking all the way over there.
Consider him packed. I didn't like his attitude... Struttin around with a cane and shit. Beat. DAVID(into walkie)
Hold up Jenkins...
David finds Elijah waiting to the side as the crowds funn Elijah offers his hand as he walks up. David doesn't take
They said I couldn't get in with my ticket. Elijah offers him the ticket. David inspects it.
It's for last week's game.
I've come to understand that... (beat)
An ill advised purchase in the parking lot. David hands Elijah back the ticket.
What do you want?
Not money. (beat)
But I appreciate your healthy cynicism in the manner. It will be wise for both of us to proceed with greatest caution.
We're not proceeding anywhere together.
We've already begun. David looks around.
One more time. What is it you want? Beat.
Why is it, do you think, that of all the professions in the world... you chose protection?
Are you for real?

You could have poured coffee in Starbucks, you could have learned to install track lighting in office buildings, you could have told people their horoscopes on the internet... You could have been one of ten thousand things... but in the end, you chose to protect people. You made that decision... and I find that very, very interesting. (beat)
Now all I need is your credit card number. Beat. Elijah smiles.
That last part was a joke. David fights it. But he smiles anyway. Beat.
I got this job because my college coach called the guy who manages the stadium. There's no hidden meaning to it. David's walkie makes NOIES on his hip.
They need me at the gate. David stares at Elijah leaning on his walking stick.
Did you really want to see the game? I can get you in.
The line of fans outside the gate has tripled in size and David and Elijah move along the line towards the turnstil
It gets heaviest ten minutes before kickoff. David bumps a guy in line wearing an army jacket. David l continues walking. David moves to a security guard near the turnstiles.
Why don't we pat down? David walks to his post near the gate and faces the crowd him.
Just give me a minute.
Is there a problem?

That guy in green. Sometimes people carry weapons in here. Then they drink too much. They're team isn't doing so well, bad things happen... We do random pat downs of the crowd to discourage people from carrying. (beat)

If he's carrying, he'll step out of line. Elijah observes as a security team pats down random males the turnstiles. The GREEN ARMY JACKETED MAN moves forward in the line. Hi watches the pat down ahead of him. He's twenty people fro David eyes him. Fifteen people away... Ten... The man coughs and steps out of the line. Elijah watches melt into the thick part of the crowd and disappear as it stadium.
AN UNLIT arched concrete passageway. The SUNLIGHT from th causing long shadows. Elijah stands waiting in the ground tunnel by himself.

head_text.subj: THE THUNDEROUS CHEERS OF THE SIXTY THOUSAND FANS IN THE S
FIELD INTO THE TUNNEL.

text: David enters the tunnel and joins Elijah. He hands him a
I got you a seat in the seven hundred level. (points straight up)
It's nose-bleed territory, but at least you won't get spit on.
How did you know that man you bumped was carrying a weapon?
Probably the army jacket. Those guys carry hunting knives and stuff for show.
You thought he was carrying a knife? Beat.
I thought he was carrying something.
But not a knife?
I got this picture of a silver handled gun tucked in his pants. (beat)
Like on t.v. Elijah stares at David. THE STADIUM CHEERS BOUNCE OFF THE
You have good instincts when it comes to things like that?
Like what?
Telling when people have done something wrong? Beat.
Yes.
Have you ever tried to develop it?
I don't know what you're asking?
You're skill. Beat.
Listen. I got to be on the sidelines during the game... You can get to your seat by taking the stairwell at-
Characters in comic books are often attributed special powers. X-ray vision, things of that sort. David exhales slowly as he stares at Elijah.
Okay, I don't want to play this game anymore.

It's an exaggeration of the truth. Maybe it's based on something as simple as instinct. Like being able to touch someone and tell whether they've done something wrong... Or the level of what they've done wrong.
The guy might not have been carrying anything.
Or he might have been carrying a silver handled gun tucked in his pants. David's WALKIE ERUPTS WITH NOISE.
I have to go now.
One last question. Beat.
Quick.
The car accident you were in... Was there anyone else involved? The two men stand very still in the tunnel.
Yes. My wife Megan. She was in the car with me. David turns and starts down the hall. David talks back ov
Have a good life Elijah and try to buy your tickets at an authorized sales location. Elijah watches as the silhouetted figure of David Dunne j the tunnel.

We are inside a customized car. The dashboard is covered foam padding. The steering wheel and gear shift have the corner and hard surface has been safe guarded. Elijah sit his car in the parking lot of the stadium. He sits as tho Beat. He finally reaches for the keys and starts up the car. He mirror and sees the man in the GREEN ARMY JACKET pass beh Elijah quickly turns and sees the man moving through the of the parking lot. Elijah takes a deep breath and turns off the engine.

Elijah's walking stick makes RHYTHMIC CLICKS on the concr The figure in the army jacket seems to move farther away Elijah starts breathing harder. He pushes himself to move hard chrome bumpers and tailpipes that jut out from the c pace through the lot. He gains on the army jacket. ELIJAH(calls out)

Hold up for a second! The man in the army jacket turns as he reaches a subway e end of the parking lot. He looks back at Elijah for a bea sees. He disappears into the subway entrance. Elijah quickens into a jog now. He hasn't done this in a He makes it with great strain to the subway. He looks into the entrance... A steep flight of stairs leads to the subway floor. The t is glimpsed before it disappears. Elijah breathes hard as he takes hold of the railing. ELIJAH(calls out)

I just want to ask you something! Elijah's VOICE ECHOES down the stairs. No response. Elijah starts his descent. THE SOUND OF A SUBWAY PULLING IN ROARS UP THE STAIRS. Elijah has to move fast. He takes the steps with less and moving with great agility... and then his foot catches on His hand slips away from the railing... He falls down the remaining part of the stairs. The FIRST heard when his hand reaches out to stop his fall. The SECOND CRACK IS MORE LIKE A CRUNCH AS HIS LEG LANDS A STAIRS. He comes to a stop in a pile on the dirty gum stained flo landing. His jaw is locked in a HORRIFIC SCREAM THAT GETS THE SUBWAY TRAIN PULLING IN. His contorted anguished face sees the turnstiles of the s green army jacketed man looks back at Elijah with a blank through the turnstile. The last thing Elijah sees before he blacks out, is the t riding up as he move through the turnstile. The SILVER HA from the belt of his pants.

David's neighborhood turns crimson as the day comes to an pulls to a stop in front of a public high school. David s security clothes. The bus pulls away as he hears his SON' David turns to the high school football field behind him. having a touch football game. Jeremy runs out from the hu David.
Was it sold out? David nods, "No."
You know how mad your mom would be if she knew you were playing football? Jeremy nods.
Are you going to tell? David nods, "No."
You want yo play the last downs? We got a big guy like you. You can play on opposite sides. David looks to the fields to see a very muscular college stands with the other children.
He's Potter's cousin. He's the starting corner back for Temple University. David stares at his son.
He going pro in the draft. They say he can run the fifty-
In under six seconds. (beat)
I've heard. David watches the cornerback being surrounded by kids. He the kids feel his flexed bicep.
I'm going to go in.
Just play one set of downs. I told them you were great.
Why'd you do that?
Just one-
Jeremy. (beat)
I'm going in. I have to do some things.
What things?
I'm going to work out.
I'll help you.
There's nothing to do. Jeremy turns back to the children and waves. JEREMY(yells)
I can't play! I'm working out with my dad! Jeremy turns back to his father and takes his hand. David who waits patiently.

The basement is dominated by storage boxes and Christmas bench press and weights are in a cluttered corner. David sits and turns at the end of the bench as Jeremy la places fifteen a pound weight on the bar. David talks ove
Why don't you rest now? I'll take it from here. You've been a big help. Jeremy goes to the opposite side of the bar and starts to
You think you could beat up Mike Tyson? I mean before he started wiggin out and eating people's ears?
No.
What if you worked out everyday for six months? You think you could beat him then?
No.

What if you only ate foods that were good for you and you worked out everyday for a year? Jeremy is breathing hard as he puts the safety collars on around to David's end of the bench. David lays back.

No. David takes hold of the barbell. Beat. He takes a deep br The weight comes off the armrests of the bench. David low pushes it back up. He does just one more rep with serious weight back on the armrest and sits up.
How much did you put on there? David twists around and looks back at the barbell. He cou circles. He turns back to Jeremy.
You put too much. That's two hundred and fifty pounds.
How much can you lift? David looks back at the weights.
That's the most I've ever lifted. (beat)
That could have been dangerous Jeremy. Why don't you go upstairs and let me finish up? Jeremy starts back to the barbell.
I'll take it off. I'll help you right. He slips off the safety collar.
You think you could have beaten up Bruce Lee? David hears the SOUND OF THE WEIGHTS SLIDING OFF THE BAR
No.
I mean if you knew karate?
No Jeremy.
What if he wasn't aloud to kick and you were really mad at him? Jeremy is breathing hard again as he finishes with the we to David. David lays back.
No. David takes hold of the bar. Lifts it off the armrest. Br are straining hard again. He raises it and lowers it two effort. The weights bang down onto the armrest. David sits up.
How much did you take off?
I lied. Beat.
You added? Jeremy nods, "Yes" slowly. David turns completely around and looks at the barbell. H on the steel bar. Beat. Nobody says anything for a long time. JEREMY(soft)
How much is it? DAVID(soft)
Two hundred and seventy. David just stares at the black steel circles on the metal sits on the bench next to his father. They both stare at JEREMY(dead serious)
Let's put more. Beat.
Okay.
David's fingers wrap around the cold metal of the bar. He and looks to Jeremy.

Why don't you move back a bit? Just to be safe. Jeremy moves back to the bottom of the stairs leading up Another deep breath as David heaves. The weight CLINKS as rest. David is full out straining now as he lowers and ra to tremble as he lifts it for the second time. BANG the w onto the rest. David sits up. He looks at his son whose eyes are wide. B
More? Beat. David nods, "Yes."
An enormous amount of black discs sits on the bar. David' metal. He talks to Jeremy who stands in his position at the bott looking at him.
You should never try anything like this. You know that right? Jeremy nods, "Yes."
What do you do if something happens? JEREMY(soft)

Get mom. David nods, "yes" before starting his deep breathing. He CLINK the weights comes off the rest. His arms are trembl face is locked in a grimace as he brings the bar down to again two times before dropping it onto the armrest. He slowly sits up.
How many did you put on that time? JEREMY(soft)
All of it.
There's no more left? Jeremy nods, "no" in a slight daze. Beat. David looks aro
What else can we use?

A set of two unopened MAB satin finish paint cans are dan handles on the outside of each side of the weights. The fours cans sway a little as the bar is heaved off of are shaking hard. He raises the weight to it's apex and b touches his chest and rises up again. David's red straine powerfully as he straightens his arms. The bar lands on the armrest with A CRASH. The paint cans they swing to stillness, one at a time. Beat. David sits up and turns back to the weights. His mouth mo discs and the cans. His lips stop moving. Beat. JEREMY(soft)
How much is it? David doesn't react. JEREMY(soft)
How much is it dad? It takes a second for David to register the question. He DAVID(soft)
About three hundred and forty. David turns and looks at his son. Jeremy's mouth is sligh his dad. Awe in his tiny eyes.

David sits on the edge of the bathroom tub. He's just sho and a t-shirt. He sits still with his elbows resting on h white tiles of the floor. THE PHONE RINGS. David gets up and walks out of the bathroom. He picks up the bathroom doorway.
Yeah, hello. WOMAN(on phone)
Is David Dunne there? Beat.
Megan? MEGAN(on phone)
Yes. Is this David?
Yeah? Megan where are you calling from? MEGAN(on phone)

My name is Megan Inverso. We went to college together. David looks at the phone. The lights for line ONE and lin David squints his eyes as he pieces together the situatio He moves back into the bathroom. The cord stretches as he edge of the bathtub.
I remember you. MEGAN(on phone)
I was hoping you would call me, but... Anyway I decided not to wait. (beat)
I was thinking, it might be nice to go to dinner together. Beat. MEGAN(soft)
...Hello? Beat.
Yeah it might be nice. We hear A SOUND ON THE OTHER END OF THE PHONE. A SOUND MU
The local Chinese restaurant. Red and gold plastic dragon A couple late-nighters are at the bar. Megan and David ar people left dining in the restaurant. They're a little dr kind of stunning.
...When you work with clients on machines, do they sometimes just jump up a level or two? Do something they didn't know they were capable of?

Not often, but it is possible. Most people get scared when they see the shadow of their limits. They don't know how long the shadow really is. They don't know how far away the real limits are standing... They stop out of fear. David nods as he takes it in. Beat. He looks down at his mein onto a fork. Megan watches him.
This is kind of strange isn't it? David nods, "yes" before taking the bite.
We're not even acting like ourselves. David touches his mouth with his napkin.
Like that. Your mouth's dirty. You tapped your napkin to your lips. You only do that when you're with someone you don't know. David looks down at his napkin.
What do I do when I'm around someone I know?
You use your sleeve. They both smile at each other. Beat. WOMAN(o.s.)
Megan? David and Megan look over to the only other table of late get up from their table. A woman about Megan's age walks
I thought it was you.
Hi. (to David)
This is Claire. Her son is in Jeremy's class. Claire and I worked on the school food drive together.
Hello. CLAIRE smiles as she stares at David. She turns to Megan. CLAIRE(mouths)
He's cute. Claire turns back to David.
I'm very happy about this. Megan mentioned to me she was considering dating again. Megan becomes still. CLAIRE(to David)
I'm sorry, what's your name? Beat. David doesn't look up.
David.
David?
This is my husband. Beat. All three people become frozen in silence. Claire looks to Megan. CLAIRE(soft)

I am so sorry. Megan nods. Claire quietly walks away form the table and joins her gr restaurant. Beat. Megan and David are the last one's left. They sit silentl looks at David's face. He's shaken. He slowly takes a sip of water and then taps his mouth wi
It's late. NO LIGHTS ARE ON EXCEPT THE ONE IN THE HALL. T dyes hair and Buddy Holly glasses. David waits as she put
He ate about six of those chocolate covered doughnut holes with his milk. He said he only had three, but I know he had six.
Okay. David is not paying attention to the girl. He watches as coat and heads to the guest room. She turns before enteri his wife make eye contact. MEGAN(soft)
Goodnight. David nods. Megan goes into her room. The guest door clos David finds the babysitter looking at him with an odd exp
My parents sleep in separate beds. David reaches into his wallet and hands the girl money.
Thank you. David opens the front door for her.
By the way, Jeremy went to sleep in his room tonight.
His room? The baby sitter nods with a smile as she walks out the fr
David walks into the darkened child's bedroom. The lump o hears movement. He smiles when he sees David. JEREMY(whispered)
I'm sleeping in my room. DAVID(soft)
I see. JEREMY(whispered)
I'm not scared. DAVID(soft)
That's great. JEREMY(whispered)
Do you know why? David nods, "No." JEREMY(whispered)
I know now. DAVID(soft)
Know what? JEREMY(whispered)
You're secret identity. (beat)
That man was right. Beat. David just stares at his son. Jeremy's eyes start t
Jeremy. Jeremy opens his eyes. DAVID(soft)
There are big guys in almost every gym who can lift that much. Beat. Jeremy's eyes start to shut. JEREMY(whispered)
You could have lifted more. (his eyes close)

Come here I want to show you something. Elijah wheels over to one of the framed sketches on the w drawing of a muscular figure shielding himself from a blo A huge ominous shadow is covering him, as if something un just out of frame.

This is from the Sentryman series. A color version of this was actually used in the second issue. Elijah points up to the drawing's face.
Look at this eyes. What do you see? David looks right at the intense eyes of the drawing.
It's fear. (beat)
He was scared. They were being honest in the beginning you see. They let him be human. (beat)
They turned him into a garden variety hero later... Then he was brave all the time. Elijah turns to David.
I followed the guy in the army jacket. David becomes still as his words register.
He had a silver handled gun tucked in the back of his pants. (beat)
Were you really injured in that car accident in college? David looks unsteady all of the sudden.
Because I think you faked it. I think you took the opportunity to end your career - no questions asked. (beat)
And I think you did it, of all things, for a women... (beat)

Not only do you have the physical traits of a hero, down somewhere in there, you have the moral code of one too. You were ready to sacrifice everything for what's right. Where can you find that these days? (beat)
Only thing you didn't realize is that you were giving up a part of yourself when you gave up football. The physical part. And you need that part desperately to feel balance again... (beat)
You can have it back now. (beat)
This was all just make believe before. What if there was someone the opposite of me? What if?... (beat)
I now believe you are the genuine article Mr. David Dunne. The kind of person we knew existed, from our history. Elijah points to the room full of pictures.
It's time for someone like you. (beat)
Bad is winning. I can feel it. Elijah looks at David with deep admiration. His voice cra of his words. Beat. David doesn't take his hands out of his pockets. DAVID(rattled)
I must have felt some lump in his back when I bumped him. Most guns have a black or silver handle. I had a fifty-fifty shot at the color.
That's not what I witnessed David.
Stop messing with my life Elijah. My son almost shot me last night. He wanted to prove you were right.
I never said you couldn't be killed. I never said that.
You have a problem, Elijah. My wife is right. Somewhere along the line one of your bones broke and your mind just broke with it. Beat.
Are you finished?
No. And I have been sick. I spent a week in a hospital when I was a boy recovering from pneumonia and almost drowning.
Two skinny eight year old kids were playing around the pool. They were dunking me. I swallowed water. They didn't know it and they almost killed me. (beat)
Heroes don't get killed like that. Normal people do. Beat. Elijah seems shaken for the first time. David stare
I don't want to see you again okay. (soft)
Now I'm finished. David turns and starts for the entrance. The BELL OF THE Dunne leaves the store.
